Award.AwardTitle: Protein Filament Formation in Activating and Modulating Enzymatic DNA Cleavage Specificity

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this research project, the PI will investigate complex regulatory mechanisms employed by unique biological systems. These investigations will build a foundation for understanding such mechanisms that are only just becoming widely appreciated, and for prediction and manipulation of their behavior for biotechnological applications. The research and associated training activities in this project will benefit both the academic research community and as well as the biotechnology industry. The program will train junior scientists to develop and implement biophysical and biochemical based conceptual approaches to understand complex enzyme regulatory mechanisms, to become leaders in this multidisciplinary field. As a result of this project, new experimental measurements will be made available to be incorporated into the biological physics curriculum to allow direct "hands-on" analyses by junior scientists in training. The PI will continue to expand upon her outreach initiatives in an effort to encourage and train scientists from a diverse range of academic and social backgrounds.

Phage-host systems are under intense evolutionary pressure, consequently they have developed remarkably ingenious mechanisms of attack and defense. This project investigates one such remarkable system: that found in Streptomyces griseus. Based on its biochemical activities, SgrAI, a nuclease from S. griseus, is postulated to be activated by binding to invading phage DNA, simultaneously expanding its DNA sequence cleavage specificity and forming polymers that may act to protect the host DNA from its resulting off-target cleavage activity. Enzyme mechanisms involving polymer or filament formation are exceedingly rare, although recent screens suggest this may be more common than previously thought. Being a potentially new paradigm for enzyme regulation, several fundamental questions arise that will be investigated in this research project, including the structure, kinetics, and biological role of the polymer. Biochemical data suggests that the polymer formed from activated SgrAI is a run-on oligomer, which has now been confirmed by the 8.6 Ã… cryo-electron microscopy structure. Although this structure shows how the SgrAI dimers bound to activating DNA associate in a repeating helical arrangement, fundamental questions such as how DNA cleavage is activated, how DNA sequence specificity is altered, and whether or not domain swapping (found in a crystal structure of two DNA bound SgrAI dimers) is present require higher resolution and therefore remain to be answered. Also important to understanding the function of the run-on oligomer is determining how formation of such an assembly, where the bound DNA appears critical for oligomer stability, accelerates rather than impedes multiple DNA cleavages. Finally, the biological role for run-on oligomer formation has been hypothesized to function in protecting the host DNA from dangerous off-target cleavages made possible via activation of SgrAI, by sequestering SgrAI on the invading phage DNA. This project will investigate the structure of the run-on oligomer using biochemical and x-ray crystallographic methods, measure kinetic steps involving polymer formation and dissociation in the reaction pathway using pre-steady state fluorescence methods, and test the postulated biological role of the polymer using in vitro and in vivo assays including phage infection challenges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Control of enzyme activity via filament formation has now become appreciated as a new enzyme mechanism that is widespread in all branches of life and for enzymes from diverse pathways including signaling, metabolism, and protein synthesis. We have studied this novel enzyme mechanism with one of the original archetypes, SgrAI. In this funding period, we have obtained the high-resolution structure of SgrAI in the filament (activated) form, using the stunning advances in high resolution cryoelectron microscopy. This structure shows how the enzyme is activated by forming the filament, and importantly, how activation is modulated by the DNA sequence bound by SgrAI and by forming the filament. We have also carried out kinetic measurements and used global modeling software to fit models to the data, deriving microscopic rate constants, and addressing a number of fundamental issues such as filament growth mechanisms, cooperativity, and how the filament both accelerates DNA cleavage within a contiguous DNA molecule, while sequestering that activity to prevent damaging cleavage on other DNA molecules in the cell. This is a completely novel and fundamental new discovery that is likely to have high impact to the understanding of enzyme mechanisms. It is also by far the most advanced analysis and description of the new filament forming enzyme mechanism, which has implications for many signaling and metabolic enzymes also known to form filaments in eukaryotic cells. The work also showed that formation of the filament does not trap the reaction product, and its limiting of the reaction rate due to filament formation is precisely the characteristic that allows for its sequestration of activity. We show how filament formation gives the activation of the enzymatic activity an advantage over conventional, non-filament enzyme mechanisms. We have also carried out studies to investigate the biological role of filament formation, by testing the effects of mutations that disrupt filament formation in the natural function of SgrAI, namely protecting its host bacteria from infection by phage. All mutations that disrupted filament formation and activation of the enzyme also disrupted this natural function of the enzyme in bacteria, supporting the hypothesized biological role of filament formation by SgrAI. Surprisingly, even relatively small knock-downs in activity had a profound effect on protection, showing how important the high speed of activation that only the filament mechanism can provide is critical to its function. This work is the most complete to date on the subject. Together these new results will greatly advance our understanding of the novel filament forming enzyme mechanism, and resulted in seventeen publications and twenty two oral presentations at conferences and universities. The PI also wrote a very comprehensive review on the subject of filament forming enzymes (published in Biophys. Rev.) and a comment in a high profile journal bringing attention to the review (published in Nature Reviews Molecular and Cell Biology) which will be a service to the community of those studying filament forming enzymes for years to come. The PI also organized and chaired a session on filament forming enzymes (given in the form of a webinar due to the pandemic) which hosted 7 speakers. The webinar was watched live by 258 individuals from around the world and is available in recorded form on the ASBMB website to be viewed at any time. These efforts also increase the visibility of the subject.

     During the funded period, outreach activities included demonstrations prepared by undergraduate students and presented to middle school students (in the course Chem 396D). These gave experience to undergraduate students (approximately 60) in teaching and interacting with middle school students (approximately 720), and gave the middle school students opportunities to learn from the undergraduate students about various scientific topics. In addition, interaction by the PI with high school students on the subject of biochemical research (during poster judging at the local regional science fair, career shadowing, and research mentoring) inspired those students to continue their interest in science. These activities increase the understanding and appreciation of science in the larger community. Finally, the mentoring and support of seventeen graduate and sixteen undergraduate students (twelve from under-represented minority groups and seventeen women) prepared them for careers in science and medicine, and increased the diversity in and visibility of under-represented groups in STEM.
